author: By Matthew Haag
title: New Yorkers Are Fleeing to the Suburbs: ‘The Demand Is Insane’
description: The pandemic is spurring home sales as prosperous city residents seek more space. One listing had 97 showings and received 24 offers.
content: Over three days in late July, a three-bedroom house in East Orange, N.J., was listed for sale for $285,000, had 97 showings, received 24 offers and went under contract for 21 percent over that price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Lucy Tompkins
title: Prosecutors Get Ballistics Report in Breonna Taylor Shooting
description: The Kentucky attorney general called the report a “critical piece” of the case, but he did not say what light it sheds on the fatal police shooting of a 26-year-old Black woman in her home.
content: Attorney General Daniel Cameron of Kentucky said on Sunday that he had received a ballistics report on the police shooting of Breonna Taylor, calling it a “critical piece” of the investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Cliff Robinson, UConn Star Who Played 18 N.B.A. Seasons, Dies at 53
description: He took the Huskies to the N.I.T. championship, and was the Sixth Man of the Year for the Trail Blazers. In 2017, he opened a marijuana dispensary.
content: Cliff Robinson, the 6-foot-10-inch forward and center who led the University of Connecticut to the 1988 National Invitation Tournament championship when the Huskies had yet to become a national collegiate power, and who played for 18 seasons in the N.B.A., died on Saturday at his home in Portland, Ore. He was 53.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Godwyn Morris and Paula Frisch
title: How to Build a Catapult From Newspaper
description: With a few folds and some tape you can soon be launching soft projectiles.
content: The use of catapults can be traced to the Greeks, Romans and Chinese more than 2,000 years ago. They were particularly popular during the Middle Ages as a way to launch projectiles over the walls of forts and castles. The catapult mechanism, also known as a lever, was, and still is, used to lift and move objects. If you have ever tossed a ball or played on a seesaw you have experienced the power of a lever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlene Cakora
title: President Trump, Don’t Leave My Brother, a Hostage, Behind
description: He was taken captive on Jan. 31 by a Taliban affiliate. The United States must win his release before it withdraws from Afghanistan.
content: LOMBARD, ILL. — When my family and I watched the Republican National Convention last week, we saw six former hostages meeting with President Trump, who boasted of his success at bringing them home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Amid Tennis’s Swirling Storms, a Stubborn Djokovic Claims a Title
description: “It has been challenging mentally and emotionally for me to stay sane,” said Novak Djokovic, who beat Milos Raonic on Saturday while working to create a controversial new players’ association.
content: After a six-month break from the tour, you might have expected tennis stars to look fresher than ever as they returned to playing in earnest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Where Are the $300 Checks?
description: New jobless claims have plateaued above 1 million, and the $300 unemployment aid checks are stuck in the system.
content: The French call it la rentrée — the ramp-up period after summer holidays end, when school starts and that buzzy September energy hits the air. To call this season different is an understatement, but rentrée we shall, as best we can. Here’s what you need to know in business and tech for the week ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 30, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 30, 2020.
content: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with an article on Page 4 about the golden age of televised theater misidentifies the production company for “Twelve Angry Men.” It was Studio One, not Playhouse 90.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can Colleges Meet the Covid Challenge?
description: Readers blame both students and administrators for campus outbreaks and discuss the social isolation forced by Covid.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: Presidential Race, Chadwick Boseman, September Books: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Will the U.S. Open Show That Big Events Can Return to New York?
description: The city is used to holding so many big events, but what is possible with the coronavirus? As the United States Open begins on Monday under a microscope, the answer could be at hand.
content: It was late-March in New York, just five months but seemingly a lifetime ago, and the leaders of tennis in the United States already knew that this year’s U.S. Open would be unlike anything they had ever experienced, if they could stage it at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart and Alan Rappeport
title: Steven Mnuchin Tried to Save the Economy. Not Even His Family Is Happy.
description: The coronavirus was an opportunity for the Treasury secretary to redefine his legacy, for better or worse.
content: One spring day, not long after President Trump signed the largest economic stimulus package in American history in March, a group of his top aides and cabinet officers gathered in the Oval Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: French Magazine Sparks Outrage Over Racist Depiction of Black Lawmaker
description: Danièle Obono, a French-Gabonese lawmaker, was portrayed as an enslaved African in a fictional narrative that she described as a “political and racist attack.”
content: PARIS — A conservative French magazine is under fire after it published a fictional narrative and illustration depicting a French lawmaker as an enslaved African who was put up for auction in the 18th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Nyameka Goniwe, Who Sought Justice in Her Husband’s Killing, Dies at 69
description: Her family became a target of South Africa’s security police, facing “constant surveillance, death threats, phone bugging,” but she fought on.
content: Nyameka Goniwe, an activist, politician and social worker who survived the death of her husband in one of apartheid-era South Africa’s most brutal extrajudicial killings and went on to campaign in vain for his assassins to be brought to justice, died on Saturday in Cradock, South Africa. She was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: The Pandemic’s Secret Formula: Backyard Workouts and Lots of Sleep
description: Limitations imposed by the coronavirus have helped, not hurt, the performances of some world-class athletes.
content: Ryan Crouser, the 2016 Olympic shot-put champion, expected to defend his gold medal in Tokyo this summer. He did not expect to enter bass-fishing tournaments to stoke competitive fires doused by a coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Shinzo Abe, India’s outbreak, Belarus: Here’s what you need to know.
content: The prime minister of Japan announced his resignation on Friday, leaving office a year early with no obvious successor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: With a Pickup Truck and an Open Mind, the Philharmonic Returns
description: The NY Phil Bandwagon’s pop-up concert series, the orchestra’s first public performances since March, debuted despite rain and other obstacles.
content: Dark clouds loomed over Downtown Brooklyn on Friday as the countertenor Anthony Roth Costanzo, standing on the bed of a pickup truck, announced to people gathered at Betty Carter Park that they were about to witness a world premiere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: There’s a New Game of Thrones in the Mediterranean
description: It’s time to listen to Germany and take a step back.
content: As if there wasn’t enough trouble around the world, two NATO allies, Greece and Turkey, have lit up a new and dangerous crisis, dragging in countries near and far. In this game of thrones, only Germany seems to have the sway to mediate a return to sanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: The Milwaukee Bucks Are Back, but They’re Not Leaving Activism Behind
description: “This group wants to do both,” Coach Mike Budenholzer said of pursuing a championship without abandoning the team’s efforts to combat police brutality and systemic racism.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — It is bound to be forgotten with time that the Milwaukee Bucks, determined as they were in their pursuit of social justice, merely wanted to forfeit a basketball game Wednesday. The Bucks initially believed that they could stage a one-game, spur-of-the-moment walkout, even during the N.B.A. playoffs, without far-reaching consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Sunday: The VMAs and ‘Driven to Abstraction’
description: The MTV Video Music Awards come to New York. And a new documentary retraces a major art world scandal.
content: THE MTV VIDEO MUSIC AWARDS 8 p.m. on MTV and the CW; Stream on vma.mtv.com. MTV’s Video Music Awards will go on this year, held at various outdoor locations in New York City. Keke Palmer will host the event, and Miley Cyrus, Lady Gaga and Ariana Grande are scheduled to perform. Lady Gaga and Ariana Grande’s collaboration “Rain on Me” was nominated for seven awards, including video and song of the year. The show will also give out two new awards created because of the coronavirus pandemic: best music video from home and best quarantine performance. Preshow performances and interviews will air ahead of the main event at 6:30 p.m. Eastern on MTV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: One Person Dead in Portland After Clashes Between Trump Supporters and Protesters
description: A man affiliated with a right-wing group was shot and killed Saturday night. A caravan of supporters of President Trump had driven into downtown Portland.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — A fatal shooting during a night of political conflict in Portland, Ore., has yet again escalated tensions in the city and further inflamed the issues of crime, protest and race that President Trump is trying to make a focus of presidential politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Javier C. Hernández
title: With a Wary Eye on China, Taiwan Moves to Revamp Its Military
description: The self-governing democracy is taking steps to bolster its armed forces in order to deter or defeat an invasion from China — with or without American help.
content: On a cloudy day last month, thousands of soldiers massed on a beach in central Taiwan for the culmination of five days of exercises intended to demonstrate how the island’s military would repel an invasion from China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Pass on an Interstate
description: Anne Marie Crinnion makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — People use an infinite variety of things and hobbies to distract themselves from troubled times, and I’m no different. My knitting needles are clicking at an impressive rate, and I have recently taken up making fermented foods, like kimchi, dill pickles and sauerkraut, because I am also a kitchen science geek. I’m sure you’re doing all sorts of interesting things, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Adam Ferguson
title: ‘A Hail Mary’: Psychedelic Therapy Draws Veterans to Jungle Retreats
description: Ayahuasca, a vomit-inducing hallucinogenic brew, draws thousands of people each year — including former soldiers — to jungle retreats that have become an unlicensed and unregulated mental health marketplace.
content: GIGANTE, Costa Rica — There was a ghostlike quality to Rudy Gonsior, an American former Special Forces sniper, on the morning he arrived at a jungle retreat to see if a vomit-inducing psychedelic brew could undo the damage years of combat had done to his mind.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Turned to See a Man Behind Me Wearing a Sweater That I Also Own’
description: Bonding at a butcher shop, a rainy day ode and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: It’s Confusing Sometimes, but the Yankees Manage to Stay on Track
description: A strange season continued as the Yankees and Mets ended a five-game weekend series at Yankee Stadium on Sunday with two extra-inning games, though each of them lasted only eight innings.
content: If you had somehow forgotten the uniqueness of the 2020 Major League Baseball season, the Yankees’ weekend series against the Mets had plenty of reminders. They played five games in three days at Yankee Stadium after a Mets player and staff member tested positive for the coronavirus, forcing a postponement of the previous weekend’s series at Citi Field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Try your hand at sabudana khichdi, or find yourself craving Melissa Clark’s roasted zucchini with garlicky bread crumbs and mozzarella.
content: The week before Labor Day is always one of the most jumbled of the year: summer and fall, looking forward and back, extremely lazy and terribly busy all at the same time. This year, things are especially shambolic. Let’s try to embrace the chaos, and cook whatever we’re hungry for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Snapped Poles, Shredded Roofs: A Long Road to Recovery After Laura
description: Hurricane Laura ravaged southwestern Louisiana, leaving weary residents to assess the toll and map a way forward. Some communities may be four weeks away from even getting power back.
content: WESTLAKE, La. — In a neighborhood along the Calcasieu River, Hurricane Laura transformed the roads into a perilous labyrinth of snapped utility poles, tangles of wires and uprooted trees. In one spot, a broken pine was suspended over the asphalt by a single strained utility line. Yet a parade of vehicles still passed beneath: People desperately wanted to get home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Koichi Nakano
title: Shinzo Abe Is Quitting, and Leaving a Trail of Scandals Behind
description: Will he ever face the Japanese people’s calls for accountability?
content: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s announcement on Friday that he would resign because of poor health was a rather abrupt end for a supposedly strong leader. Mr. Abe has ruled Japan, most recently, for a record seven years and eight months: He is the country’s longest-serving prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: What Happened in Portland? Here’s What We Know
description: A man was shot and killed after supporters of President Trump clashed with counterprotesters.
content: Portland, Ore., has had nightly protests since the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Justice Dept. Never Fully Examined Trump’s Ties to Russia, Ex-Officials Say
description: The former deputy attorney general maneuvered to keep investigators from completing an inquiry into whether the president’s personal and financial links to Russia posed a national security threat.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department secretly took steps in 2017 to narrow the investigation into Russian election interference and any links to the Trump campaign, according to former law enforcement officials, keeping investigators from completing an examination of President Trump’s decades-long personal and business ties to Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Schram
title: After Leading N.H.L. Play Stoppage, Golden Knights and Canucks Redraw Swords
description: Players from the most tempestuous series of the postseason pushed hockey to join other leagues that had suspended play in response to the police shooting of Jacob Blake in Wisconsin.
content: On Thursday, when the N.H.L. Players Association announced that there would be a two-day suspension of the postseason, the league showed solidarity with other professional leagues that shut down in the wake of another police shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
title: Shift on Election Briefings Could Create an Information Gap for Voters
description: The elimination of in-person election security briefings to Congress could leave the public with a diminished understanding of the threats facing the election as it enters a critical phase.
content: The decision by the nation’s top intelligence official to halt classified, in-person briefings to Congress about foreign interference in a presidential election that is just nine weeks away exposes the fundamental tension about who needs to know this information: just the president, or the voters whose election infrastructure, and minds, are the target of the hacking?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Jürgen Schadeberg, Whose Photos Chronicled Apartheid, Dies at 89
description: He gained rare entree into segregated Black communities, and took pictures that book-ended the career of Nelson Mandela.
content: Jürgen Schadeberg, a German-born photographer who survived the turmoil of wartime Berlin, then emigrated to South Africa, creating some of the most potent and enduring images of Nelson Mandela and chronicling the increasingly violent imposition of apartheid on Black lives, died on Saturday at his home in La Drova, Spain. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘In the Line of Fire’
description: For less than $2 an hour, California’s female inmate firefighters undertake grueling physical work and sometimes risk their lives.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: Malcolm X, Laurence Fishburne and ‘the Theater of Your Mind’
description: The Oscar-nominated actor narrates “The Autobiography of Malcolm X” in an audiobook project he says “doesn’t change my perspective so much as it amplifies it.”
content: Published in 1965, “The Autobiography of Malcolm X” was not, originally, Malcolm X’s idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Taliban Violated Afghan Deal With Shelling of American Bases, U.S. Officials Say
description: Rockets that U.S. officials say were fired by the insurgent group have landed around two bases used by American forces. A Taliban commander denied involvement.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Rockets launched at a U.S. military base and a joint U.S.-Afghan airfield in southern Afghanistan in recent weeks are believed to have been fired by the Taliban, according to three American military officials, in what would amount to a clear breach of the peace agreement between the United States and the insurgent group.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hidden Trump Voters, or Remorseful?
description: A reader says some of them may simply be suffering from buyer’s remorse. Also: Female authors and translators; studying ant behavior.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Samira Wiley and Uzo Aduba Still Remember Struggling
description: In a conversation, the actors look back on how “Orange Is the New Black” changed their lives and discuss their Emmy-nominated roles in “The Handmaid’s Tale” and “Mrs. America.”
content: The 72nd Primetime Emmy Awards will be given out on Sept. 20, so we’re talking to pairs of nominated actors as we look ahead to the ceremony. (Whatever it ends up being.) For a full list of Emmy nominees and other coverage of TV’s top awards, visit nytimes.com/Emmys.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: District by District, a Plan for In-Person Schooling Falls Apart
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 30, 2020.
content: “I’ve been to student funerals. I would prefer not to go to any more.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, John Branch, John Eligon, Reid J. Epstein, Dan Levin and Marc Stein
title: Stories of 2020: Five Lives Caught in a Year of Upheaval and Pain
description: In a year that has filled morgues, emptied schools, shuttered workplaces, swelled unemployment lines and polarized the electorate, these are a few of the Americans struggling to respond.
content: WASHINGTON — And then Chadwick Boseman died. On a Friday night, a way-too-young Hollywood star who had inspired fans around the world suddenly was gone without warning. After everything else, it was just too much for many. “I HATE 2020” began trending on Twitter. Not for the first time and probably not for the last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump Embraces Fringe Theories on Protests and the Coronavirus
description: In a Twitter barrage, the president advanced conspiracy theories claiming that protests are an organized coup and that the virus death toll is inflated. He also reposted a call to imprison New York’s governor.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump unleashed an especially intense barrage of Twitter messages over the weekend, embracing fringe conspiracy theories claiming that the coronavirus death toll has been exaggerated and that street protests are actually an organized coup d’état against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Dermatology Has a Problem With Skin Color
description: Common conditions often manifest differently on dark skin. Yet physicians are trained mostly to diagnose them on white skin.
content: In the spring, teenagers started showing up at doctors’ offices in droves with angry red and purple blisters on their fingers and toes. The latest unexpected feature of the coronavirus infection fascinated the public, and suddenly photographs of so-called Covid toes were everywhere on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Review: Bringing Borges to Life in ‘Footnote for the End of Time’
description: Theater in Quarantine’s latest small-scale, digitally savvy production is an adaptation of a Borges story about a man stopping time to stare down death.
content: “We cross infinity with every step; we meet eternity in every second,” wrote Rabindranath Tagore. Tagore could have been talking about the beautifully labyrinthine work of the Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges, which works like a mathematical equation without end, and where time is as flexible as putty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Phoenix Settles With Black Family After Police Drew Guns Over Reported Doll Theft
description: The settlement, which is for more than $470,000, comes after an episode last year in which officers responded to a shoplifting complaint at a Family Dollar store.
content: The city of Phoenix has reached a settlement with a Black family for more than $470,000 after a widely viewed video last year showed police officers drawing their weapons and shouting expletives at the family while responding to a shoplifting complaint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Banksy-Funded Rescue Vessel Evacuated After Distress Call
description: About 400 migrants remain stranded aboard several rescue vessels in the central Mediterranean as international aid groups urge European officials to let them come ashore.
content: The British street artist Banksy has accused European officials of ignoring maritime distress calls from non-Europeans after he helped fund a rescue vessel to assist migrants stranded in the central Mediterranean for days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Looking to Reopen, Colleges Become Labs for Coronavirus Tests and Tracking Apps
description: Universities are pioneering technology that could help society combat the pandemic.
content: Thousands of students returning to the Rochester Institute of Technology in New York this month are being asked to wear masks in public, register their health status online each day and electronically log classroom visits for contact tracing if a coronavirus outbreak occurs. But the most novel effort at the school to measure and limit virus spread will require little effort and come quite naturally.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Breonna Taylor’s Life Was Changing. Then the Police Came to Her Door.
description: An ex-boyfriend’s run-ins with the law entangled her even as she tried to move on. Interviews, documents and jailhouse recordings help explain how she landed in the middle of a deadly drug raid.
content: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Breonna Taylor had just done four overnight shifts at the hospital where she worked as an emergency room technician. To let off some steam, she and her boyfriend, Kenneth Walker, planned a date night: dinner at a steakhouse, followed by a movie in bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr. and Thomas Kaplan
title: U.S. Will Revive Global Virus-Hunting Effort Ended Last Year
description: A federal agency is resurrecting a version of Predict, a scientific network that for a decade watched for new pathogens dangerous to humans. Joe Biden has also vowed to fund the effort.
content: A worldwide virus-hunting program allowed to expire last year by the Trump administration, just before the coronavirus pandemic broke out, will have a second life — whatever the outcome of the presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Belarus President Hunkers Down as Crowds Demand He Leave
description: Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the autocratic president of Belarus since 1994, is no longer brutally suppressing demonstrations that have gone on for weeks, but he shows no signs of going away.
content: MINSK, Belarus — Tens of thousands of people marched on the palace of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus on Sunday, demanding he resign, as large-scale protests against the longtime, authoritarian leader entered their fourth week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Coronavirus Cases Top 6 Million
description: The jump in infections comes as the daily rate continues to decline. New Delhi is reopening its subway, even as India sets global records for new cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Preaching Equality, Start-Up Didn’t Practice It With Employees
description: Current and former workers at Carta, a hot Silicon Valley fintech company, said they were belittled, excluded and punished if they spoke up.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Onstage at an industry conference last year, Henry Ward, chief executive of the financial technology start-up Carta, described his vision for transforming the way that workers get paid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi, Michael Corkery and Carlos Mureithi
title: Big Oil Is in Trouble. Its Plan: Flood Africa With Plastic.
description: Faced with plunging profits and a climate crisis that threatens fossil fuels, the industry is demanding a trade deal that weakens Kenya’s rules on plastics and on imports of American trash.
content: Confronting a climate crisis that threatens the fossil fuel industry, oil companies are racing to make more plastic. But they face two problems: Many markets are already awash with plastic, and few countries are willing to be dumping grounds for the world’s plastic waste.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Jeanette Carlson, Who Fought Apartheid, Dies at 91
description: She was deported from South Africa in 1971 for her activity and vowed never to return. “It was disgusting to live in that kind of environment.”
content: Jeanette Carlson, an anti-apartheid activist who with her husband fought against the racist South African government and who with her family was eventually deported, died on Aug. 18 at home in Silver Spring, Md. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times
